content:
Here is the email content, masquerading as an airline ticket confirmation, which asks the targeted victim to click on a link. 
It was designed so that a victim downloads a $7z$ file from the link shown in figure 1 that contains this new variant of HawkEye and runs it on the victim's system. 
Unfortunately, on initial analysis the URL was not available and I received a "404 Not Found" message in the browser. 
Browsing to its main page. It turned out to be an FTP service, containing several related network folders about this campaign, with most containing the same malware sample (Figure 2). 
After the downloaded $7z$ file was decompressed, we retrieved the EXE file "TICKET%2083992883992AIR8389494VERVED37783PDF.exe", which is the new variant of HawkEye.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text states that the victim is asked to click on a link, indicating a process-to-socket relationship where the process is the victim's clicking action and the socket is the link to be clicked.   [Relationships]: <process:clicking,asked to click on,socket:link>. 
2. [CoT]: The text mentions that the victim downloads a 7z file from the link, indicating a process-to-file relationship where the process is the victim's downloading action and the file is the 7z file to be downloaded.   [Relationships]: <process:downloads,file:7z file>. 
3. [CoT]: The text states that the victim runs the 7z file on their system, indicating a process-to-file relationship where the process is the victim's running action and the file is the 7z file to be run.   [Relationships]: <process:runs,file:7z file>. 
4. [CoT]: The text mentions that the 7z file is decompressed to retrieve an EXE file, indicating a process-to-file relationship where the process is the decompressing action and the file is the 7z file to be decompressed.   [Relationships]: <process:decompresses,file:7z file>. 
5. [CoT]: The text states that after decompression, the EXE file is retrieved, indicating a process-to-file relationship where the process is the retrieving action and the file is the EXE file to be retrieved. [Relationships]: <process:retrieves,file:TICKET%2083992883992AIR8389494VERVED37783PDF.exe>.

content:
Once HawkEye started, it spawned a suspended child process, "RegAsm.exe", from the Microsoft .Net framework installation directory â€“ which is a tool for Assembly Registration. Meanwhile, HawkEye extracted a PE file into its memory and then moved the PE file into "RegAsm.exe". The dynamically extracted PE file is the main program of HawkEye. It's called "HawkEye_RegAsm," to differentiate these files in the analysis. HawkEye_RegAsm began running after resuming running "RegAsm.exe" after being suspended. 
HawkEye_RegAsm is a .Net written program, which is packed by ConfuserEx v1.0.0 to protect itself. This creates a big challenge for analysts to read its code and analyze it. The code was actually totally obfuscated, as shown in figure 3. 
After sleeping 10 seconds, HawkEye_RegAsm starts its work on the victim's system. Through analysis so far, it appears to mainly perform the following functions: 
1> Set up clipboard logger   
2> Set up keyboard logger   
3> Spawn another two child processes "vbc.exe", both from the .Net framework directory as well. $4>$ Send collected data to an email address using SMTP from time to time (every 10 minues). 
HawkEye_RegAsm starts a thread to perform the above tasks, and then every 10 minutes it sends its collected information to its Yandex email address. 
HawkEye_RegAsm sets up a clipboard and keyboard logger using Windows-native APIs (such as SetWindowsHookEx, SetClipboardViewer, etc.) Its local functions can record victim's behaviors when the victim types on the keyboard as well as when copying data into the system clipboard. 
Figure 4 shows an example of the information that HawkEye_RegAsm collected from its keyboard and clipboard logger, as well as the software title from when the event occurred.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: HawkEye started and spawned a suspended child process "RegAsm.exe" from the Microsoft .Net framework installation directory. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye,spawned,process:RegAsm.exe>. 
2. [CoT]: HawkEye extracted a PE file into its memory and then moved the PE file into "RegAsm.exe". [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye,moved,file:PE file>. 
3. [CoT]: "RegAsm.exe" was resumed running by HawkEye_RegAsm after being suspended. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_Regasms, resumed running,process:RegAsm.exe>. 
4. [CoT]: HawkEye_Regasms sends collected data to an email address using SMTP. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_Regasms,sends,socket:email address>. 
5. [CoT]: HawkEye_Regasms sends its collected information to its Yandex email address every 10 minutes. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_Regasms,sends,socket:Yandex email address>. 
6. [CoT]: HawkEye_Regasms sets up a clipboard logger using Windows-native APIs. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_Regasms,sets up,process:clipboard logger>. 
7. [CoT]: HawkEye_Regasms sets up a keyboard logger using Windows-native APIs. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_Regasms,sets up,process:keyboard logger>.

content:
HawkEye_RegAsm performs a similar task as to the RegAsm.exe. It spawns two suspended child processes, "vbc.exe", which are from the same directory as RegAsm.exe. HawkEye dynamically extracts two PE files into its memory, which are then copied into the two newly created child processes of "vbc.exe". It also modifies its ThreadContext data (It calls the API, SetThreadContext) and makes its entry point to the transfered PE file. When "vbc.exe" resumes running it can be executed. It's a trick that malware often performs to camouflage itself behind of a normal process. 
The two "vbc.exe" processes collect credentials from the victim's system. One is used to collect the credentials of browsers. The other one focuses on email clients and IM clients to steal credentials and profiles. Both PE files injected into "vbc.exe" have the same code framework. They first call a function to collect credentials and save them in memory, and second, it reads the collected data, formats it, and saves it to a tmp file from its command line parameter. 
Figure 5 shows HawkEye calling the CreateProcess API to start one of the two "vbc.exe" processes, with the parameter shown below in the "Locals" sub-tab. You can see the full path of "vbc.exe". "/stext ""C:\Users\\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\AppData\Local\Temp\tmpBE3D.tmp""" is the parameter passed to it. The tmp file name is random and different from the two "vbc.exe" processes, which temporarily saves collected credentials. 
The two PE files are not packer protected and not .Net written program.   
The first "vbs.exe" collects credentials from victim's browsers and the system credential manager for IE. In my analysis, this variant of HawkEye focuses on the following browsers: 
Microsoft Internet Explorer, Google Chrome, Apple Safari, Opera, Mozilla Sunbird, Mozilla Firefox, Mozilla Portable Thunderbird, Mozilla SeaMonkey, YandexBrowser, Vivaldi browser, and more. 
Figure 6 shows some strings defined in the ASM code of the browsers that the HawkEye malware wants to collect credentials from. 
The collected credentials are then saved into the tmp file from its command line parameter. HawkEye_RegAsm keeps checking this tmp file, and once the credentials are collected, it is done. HawkEye_RegAsm then reads the entire data of this tmp file into its memory and the deletes it immediately. 
The second PE file in "vbc.exe"collects profile and credential information of the email and IM software client installed on a victim's machine. 
The clients it targets are: 
Qualcomm Eudora, Mozilla Thunderbird, MS Office Outlook, IncrediMail, Groupmail, MSNMessenger, Yahoo!Pager/Yahoo!Messenger and Windows Mail. 
Below is an example list that HawkEye stole from the Chrome browser on my test machine. As you can see, it includes login URL, Browser name, User name, Password, Created time, and the full path of the file where the collected information came from. 
The second PE file in "vbc.exe" not only collects the client's login username and password, but also profile information, such as the recipent Server address, recipient Server Port, protocol Type (POP3), SMTP Server, SMTP Port, etc. Figure 7 shows a screenshot of Ollydbg when "vbc.exe" was about to write the collected recipient Server addresses into its tmp file. It writes one line once. The same tmp file is finally read by HawkEye_RegAsm and then deleted. 
On my test machine, I only installed MS Outlook with one account. My test account and server profile were collected and put in the structure shown below, which would normally be sent to the attacker's email box.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text states that HawkEye_RegAsm performs a similar task as RegAsm.exe and spawns two suspended child processes "vbc.exe".   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,spawns,process:vbc.exe>. 
2. [CoT]: The text mentions that HawkEye dynamically extracts two PE files into its memory, which are then copied into the two newly created child processes of "vbc.exe".   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,copies,file:PE files>. 
3. [CoT]: The text describes that HawkEye_RegAsm modifies its ThreadContext data by calling the API SetThreadContext.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,calls,socket:SetThreadContext>. 
4. [CoT]: The text states that HawkEye_RegAsm makes its entry point to the transferred PE file.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,makes,file:PE file>. 
5. [CoT]: The text mentions that HawkEye_RegAsm keeps checking the tmp file for collected credentials.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,checks,file:tmp file>. 
6. [CoT]: The text describes that HawkEye_RegAsm reads the entire data of the tmp file into its memory.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,reads,file:tmp file>. 
7. [CoT]: The text states that HawkEye_RegAsm deletes the tmp file immediately after reading its data.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,deletes,file:tmp file>. 
8. [CoT]: The text mentions that the second PE file in "vbc.exe" collects credentials from the victim's system, including browsers, email clients, and IM clients.   [Relationships]: <process:vbc.exe,collects,socket:credentials>. 
9. [CoT]: The text describes that the two PE files in "vbc.exe" save the collected credentials in memory.   [Relationships]: <process:vbc.exe,saves,file:credentials in memory>. 
10. [CoT]: The text states that the PE files read the collected data and save it to a tmp file from their command-line parameter.   [Relationships]: <process:vbc.exe,reads,file:tmp file>. 
11. [CoT]: The text mentions that HawkEye_RegAsm reads the data from the tmp file into its memory.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,reads,file:tmp file>. 
12. [CoT]: The text describes that HawkEye_RegAsm deletes the tmp file immediately after reading its data.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,deletes,file:tmp file>. 
13. [CoT]: The text states that HawkEye_RegAsm collects credentials from the victim's browsers, including Microsoft Internet Explorer.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,collects,socket:Microsoft Internet Explorer>. 
14. [CoT]: The text mentions that HawkEye_RegAsm targets the system credential manager for IE.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,targets,socket:system credential manager>. 
15. [CoT]: The text describes that the collected credentials are saved into the tmp file from the PE file's command-line parameter.   [Relationships]: <process:vbs.exe,saves,file:tmp file>. 
16. [CoT]: The text states that the second PE file in "vbc.exe" collects profile and credential information from email and IM software clients.   [Relationships]: <process:vbc.exe,collects,socket:profile and credential information>. 
17. [CoT]: The text mentions that the second PE file writes the collected recipient Server addresses into its tmp file.   [Relationships]: <process:vbc.exe,writes,file:tmp file>. 
18. [CoT]: The text describes that HawkEye_RegAsm reads the data from the tmp file and then deletes it.   [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,reads,file:tmp file>. 
19. [CoT]: The text states that the tmp file would normally be sent to the attacker's email box. [Relationships]: <process:vbc.exe,sends,file:tmp file>.

content:
Ok. Now let's go back to the main process of HawkEye_RegAsm, which controls all tasks of HawkEye and sends the victim's credentials. In its main program, it calls Thread.Sleep(600000), and pauses while collecting credentials every 10 minutes. That is, it reports the collected data to attacker the once every 10 minutes. 
It first sends an HTTP request, http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com, to ask for my machine's public IP. This is a way to ensure that the victim's machine is able to access the internet. If it did not reply with a public IP, it stops sending collected data to the email box. In addition, the IP appears in the email subject so it can identify victims. 
The attacker's email is in Yandex.mail, whose email account and password are used when sending collected data through the Yandex SMTP server. That's why I was able to get the attacker's email credentials while tracking the main program. You can see the screenshot in figure 8 when I was debugging it. 
Every ten minutes it sends packets such as that shown in Figure 9 to tell the attacker about what it has collected from the victim's machine using the keylogger, clipboard, browser credentials, and IM and email client credentials and profiles. 
Visiting the attacker's account, we can see what the attacker has harvested, as shown in figure 10.
relationship:
1. [CoT]: The text states that HawkEye_RegAsm pauses every 10 minutes by calling Thread.Sleep(600000), indicating a process-to-process relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls Thread.Sleep. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,process:Thread.Sleep>. 
2. [CoT]: The text mentions that HawkEye_RegAsm sends an HTTP request to http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com, showing a process-to-socket relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls the socket http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,socket:http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com>. 
3. [CoT]: The text describes that HawkEye_RegAsm sends packets to the attacker to report collected data, indicating a process-to-socket relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls the socket described in the text. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,socket:packets described in text>. 
4. [CoT]: The text states that the attacker uses a Yandex SMTP server to send collected data, showing a process-to-socket relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls the Yandex SMTP server. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,socket:Yandex SMTP server>. 
5. [CoT]: The text mentions that HawkEye_RegAsm collects data using a keylogger, indicating a process-to-process relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls the keylogger process. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,process:keylogger>. 
6. [CoT]: The text describes that HawkEye_RegAsm collects data from the clipboard, showing a process-to-process relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls the clipboard process. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,process:clipboard>. 
7. [CoT]: The text states that HawkEye_RegAsm collects browser credentials, indicating a process-to-process relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls the browser process. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,process:browser>. 
8. [CoT]: The text mentions that HawkEye_RegAsm collects IM and email client credentials and profiles, showing a process-to-process relationship where HawkEye_RegAsm controls the IM and email client processes. [Relationships]: <process:HawkEye_RegAsm,controls,process:IM and email client>.
